The best fallout experience. With mods, the possibilities are endless, but to think this game is considered a classic now. Man, have I gotten old.

Side quest and dialogue keep you engaged 
DLCs are not required but extremely fun 
commit till the end of the game gets better throughout the story 
Peak game

It's New Vegas. Arguably the best 3D Fallout ever made. Has it's issues, mods are needed to bring it to modern standards, but with a little bit of work, and a few frustrating failed mod installs, it'll be one of the best game experiences you've ever had.

15 years later I am shocked with how good this game is. Itâ€™s the kind of game that surprises you with how immersive/diverse the game content is. The characters and dialog are some of the best in any game ever made. A few of the game mechanics and open world design can be a bit janky by todayâ€™s standards but itâ€™s easy to overlook that with how much the game has to offer. The DLCs are great and add a massive amount of content to the game. 

The only real downside is that you pretty much HAVE to mod the game (4gb patch, NVAC, NVTF) to get it to run smoothly/not crash every 15 mins. Itâ€™s annoying but it makes a night and day difference in game performance.

This is the kind of game that you play once when you're a teenager and it changes you.
I've heard a lot of people joke that they played it as a teenage boy, and still play it as an adult woman.

For me it changed how I make decisions carefully weighing everything I do as to make sure that I make the right ones, for the right reasons. and if I can't I'll just do what I can.

The playtime doesn't lie, if you've got a hankering for a free roam rpg with guns, explosives and the occasional sword, bat or giant metal gauntlet, set in a post-apocalyptic America with secrets and quests no matter where you end up, you can do a whole lot worse than ten bucks for a fifteen year old game. Hell I'd even recommend paying the extra ten and go ahead and get the dlc.

Nexus Mods Crash Fix Simulator. Obsidian needed meth to release this as good as it was.

Runs great on Linux, but any player will need to duct tape this.
Arguably one of the best Fallouts ever made. Instant classic. Not as many bells and whistles as Fallout 4, but highly recommend picking this up.
this is really one of the deepest Fallout games to date. there's so much going on it keeps you busy, if you wanna be. otherwise, there's lots to explore, lot's of factions, lots of fun.
Ring-a-ding baby, Masterpiece never gets old.
My game crashed from opening a door, 10/10 would crash again
Great Fallout game and the day they release a remake of this will be the day I call out of work

I play offline. I have over 100 hours in this game.
I really love the role-playing element of Fallout New Vegas. You can be whatever kind of person you want. You can change or grow as you see fit with the story, or ignore the story.
You cannot be all things to all people, you have to make choices, and I like that.
I like this much more than Fallout 3. I don't know why, I just do. 
There are definitely some bugs. Random crashes being the biggest one. The VATS system sometimes stalls, and if you're backed up against a wall, good luck trying to get an attack off.
But overall, I really like this one.
Possibly the best game ever made, despite being a buggy mess.

Played this on xbox360 when came out. And oh boy that crash on pc got me 3 hours in. So ended up looking for my xbox360 still the best game of its time got better with age for some reason. Also didn't know there was death claws in game when first played and got jump scared. if you want to play on pc fix the bug before playing.

Amazing game, incredible storyline and characters. The only part of this game that gets stale is the combat otherwise unless you play it religiously you should be entertained for hours at an end. I highly reccomend this game for anyone wanting to get into fallout, since unlike 1 and 2 it is more accessible on the gameplay spectrum. Last thing please have fun with it, don't follow any character builds- be yourself and experience the mojave wasteland in your own unique way. Thanks for reading this :)

about a year ago i got into the fallout franchise and decided to start with this game because i am from Las Vegas and in all honesty seeing my hometown in a post apocalyptic world is pretty awesome. the dialogue is absolutely amazing and the story is super interesting. the graphics are obviously potato since it is an old game but for its time they are not bad. i am currently on my 3rd playthrough and every time i start over i find something new. i do wish you could keep playing after finishing the main quest and that it had more than 50 levels but regardless it is an amazing game

First play through finished. 

Initial Thoughts: 

1st play through: NCR ending

Fallout: New Vegas is one of the best RPG games I have had the pleasure of playing. With most actions having consequences, a robust cast of characters and questing to go for as long as you can take it, this really delivers an amazing experience. I have been playing through all the Fallout games in 2025, and so far this is 2nd only to Fallout 2, only for my personal opinion though. Opposed to Fallout 3, this game continues the legacy that The Chosen One had left behind in the Mojave, but with a new degree of freedom.

Story & Questing: It took a while for me to really lock in with the story here, it often has an issue to me where there are so many different things to do, it is hard to just pick a route. Each route that the game offers has their own rewards, and their own downsides which makes for very good replay-ability. I Will be coming back for another play through just to see how the other choices change the characters that I grew to love. 10/10 experience for me, with amazing lore and engaging story beats that leave you wanting more. My favorite part is that this game makes your input feel valued in the story it is telling, and how every choice has been thought of and rewards the player for being curious. The Questing at times can still feel tedious as it goes for these 3D RPG's, but the majority of the time the environment is so malleable that it doesn't feel like a chore. Your cave dungeon run to grab a special item is accompanied by fun enemies, rewarding loot, and good music on the radio. The quest to quest progression in towns like Novak is extremely engaging, making you really want to figure out the secrets, help allies, or make enemies.

Roleplaying: Man, this game offers everything I want in an RPG. Usually my first play through I enjoy being the good guy, and this game makes that a very fun experience, with the player actually feeling good about what they've done. Every conversation has great choices, where you can increase or decrease your karma instantly by saying the wrong thing, getting rid of the mindless pressing A just to get through it. (I don't, some people do) I also enjoy how the game isn't afraid to have you make mistakes by trying to do the right thing. Too many games now really make it just so easy to be the perfect good guy, but if you actually don't know what will happen in some of these quests you could very well kill your companion, or worse.

Gameplay: While this is still another clunky 3D Fallout game, it has less issues for my personal play style. The combat feels better, along with the difficulty scaling of the enemies. Deathclaws are feared, and so are the Legionaries with their fists of steel. The linear world progression is fun, giving you all the time to 100% each town you go through and grow your relationships as the courier, whether you want to be disliked or liked.

DLC: This game delivers a narrative that makes you want to keep chasing The Flagbearer all day. I couldn't get enough of Elijah and Courier 5. I read every log, hacked every terminal, expended every ounce of dialogue I could and I still was left wanting more. Learning the past of your character is such a grounding experience, especially after everything you have done feels like a facade after lonesome road. This collection of DLC has been my favorite out of any game ever to play back to back, and I can't get enough. The gameplay for each suggested their own challenges like Sierra Madre being more sneak focused, and that was something I really enjoyed! I think it is fun to divvy up your gameplay styles in DLC like these in order to make sure the player really gets to try it all out.

Overall: This game was an absolute blast, I would love to play it again right now but I'm saving all my replays after I finish the franchise. I cannot recommend it enough, and I really do think this is a top 20 game of all time for me. The only downside is the crashing, and some fast travel areas, but I really am just nitpicking.

 Fantastic game, 10/10.
peak played this for many years, on steam and mostly on xbox 360. top 2 fallout games and its not number 2

I might not have chosen Wild Wasteland as one of my traits, but New Vegas didn't let that stop it from letting me have a more whimsical journey through the Mojave! Just when I thought I've seen it all, throughout my travels I've encountered: An NCR soldier typing on an invisible terminal, a legendary variant of the common radscorpion that seems to be able to conceal its whole body underground (except for the tail), a fiend that was able to soar through the sky after I *maybe* shot him in the dome (I get that these guys love their jet, but they ain't supposed to become one!), a Boomer child that was able to bend the fabric of reality by becoming a moving statue, & a rather strange encounter in Zion Valley in which a giant yao guai practiced its special 'stuck-in-the-wall' jutsu while simultaneously charging at my friend Waking Cloud. She took this as a challenge & began to charge at the yao guai, the result being the two of them charging at each other but unable to attack. I'm still rather unfamiliar with the customs of the Sorrows Tribe (apart from their ongoing feud with yao guai), so I simply crouched down & observed. Seemingly taking this as inspiration, Waking Cloud crouched down as well & smacked the bear with her bear glove straight through the wall it was stuck in, dealing the finishing blow. After that I definitely made the right decision to take the war to the White Legs.

Oh, I also encountered the dreaded infinite loading screen & had to restart my computer because ALT + TAB wasn't working. Thanks gamebryo engine
For a game that is 15 years old the story is great.The mechanics are great too honestly a peak game for a game that was made in the 2010's. Absolute Cinema
This is the best fallout game in the entire series. I highly recommend you buy and experience peak gaming!

There are few visions as bold as New Vegas; few legends shared as impulsively. An oppressively immersive role-playing game, set not in a fantasy kingdom or a science fiction colony, but in a land of cynicism and alcohol; a place where your ability to play blackjack is often more important than your ability to shoot a rifle. No two factions share the same ideology, and not a single one is even close to being completely moral. There are no happy endings, no easy decisions, no motivations other than more excuses to walk and walk and see and see. Like a ghost. You do have a bullet in your head, after all. The game is uncomfortably cohesive, and at times the details of its player freedom are unnervingly intricate. The vision is too big, of course. The game barely functions at times. Plotlines flicker out as desperate developers reach a deadline far too close and far too cruel. Yes, in some ways, the game is a failure. Yes, its scope often serves to disappoint. Yes, I am transgender. And no, no other Fallout even comes close.

It's the best Fallout game. Period. Crazy how Bethesda still can't top this. It literally took the original creators of the franchise to make a great Fallout game. You can tell how much Bethesda hates the fact that people love this over every other Fallout. Don't get me wrong, Fallout 3 and 4 a great games. But they will NEVER top this. I own this game on every console and obviously PC.
Great core game that lends itself to incredible storytelling in the DLCs as well. If you're getting just the base game, you'll have a great deal of fun, but the DLC really make this game excel.

Best Fallout game ever published by Bethesda. It blows Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 out of the water. The story is great, game play is the same as Fallout 3 so both have really good game play. I have played this game way more on console growing up when it first came out. As a long time Fallout fan I personally think this one is the best and would recommend anyone to play this game that is a fan of RPG's. I have not played any of the DLC's for this game but I am going to pick them up soon. I ended up getting a steam deck recently. This game runs great on the steam deck, honestly better than it did on my pc or on console. I have some mods installed and no crashes which is insane. Runs at a stable 90fps with frame drops only in VATS. 10/10 recommend this game to anyone that wants to play a good Fallout game.

Takes some simple modding to get it to run well, so take that into account for my review.

A fun RPG with some interesting writing, quests with actually multiple possible outcomes, locations with interesting lore and companions with interesting personalities.

However, given you need some mods to help with stability, I recommend you get the game on sale.
The best Fallout game. No level-scaled enemies, skill-based dialogue options (not just Persuasion), Perks, weapon mods. Obsidian played Fallout 1 and 2.

I can't speak for the DLC on this one as I've only ever played the base game.

That being said, this is probably the best modern Fallout has or will ever be again... no surprise then that it wasn't made by Bethesda but Obsidian. Unlike Fallout 3 or even Fallout 4 this game *feels* like an RPG instead of an FPS with dialogue trees. Unlike other entries in the 3D era of this franchise, New Vegas feels like it gives the player agency in ways that the other entries do not. The characters are well written, the questlines are interesting. Something that Bethesda has struggled with for a long time. I may just hate Bethesda, but I feel like until they can release something at or above New Vegas in quality it's deserved to a degree... especially since Obsidian didn't get their bonus for this game due to it's Metacritic score being one point off.

There is one caveat for the whole thing though... well... two. Despite being made by Obsidian, Bethesda gave them one hell of a tight deadline to work with... and with something as expansive as New Vegas... it's no wonder the game isn't actually finished. I'm not talking about story or quests or anything like that. I'm talking about it from a mechanical standpoint. The underlying codebase for the game is... bugged to hell and back. This leads into the second caveat, it's still the same horrid engine Bethesda has used from Morrorwind to Starfield. What's even worse is that New Vegas came out in 2010, right around the turn of 64-bit multithreaded processors becoming more common... but New Vegas still runs on the 32-bit version of Gamebryo. I talk down on Gamebryo often, and to be honest the engine itself IS capable... but Bethesda has retooled the hell out of their version of it and broke it in so many ways.... so when they handed it off to Obsidian to create New Vegas the tools and assets and internal logic they were working with, combined with it being the 32-bit version of the engine... means that on modern hardware it's almost impossible to play without mods, and mods still can't fix *everything*. Memory leaks, random crashes, it's unstable at it's core. It's a house of cards.


TLDR: I absolutely recommend it, but it's unstable on more modern hardware.
u can gamble , hire sex robots, roleplay being roman, and be a cowboy all while listening to johnny gutiar
Best Fallout game and one of the best, if not best, CRPGs of all time!

One of the best games I've ever played, ignore all the " it crashes so often! " shit, It had at the most, 4-5 crashes through an entire 25 hour game for me, the story is rich and so beautifully made, every faction is unique and has a telling story, it truely is one of the games of all time
easily the best fallout game, tied with 3 in terms of story but definitely most fun

Best fallout game out there, Rich story, and the graphics still look pretty good.
Classic game, excellent part of fallout series worth the hours of gameplay.

This game sucks but is also amazing. To anyone dealing with CONSTANT crashes, DISABLE YOUR AUTOSAVES.
I still remember buying this at launch for my xbox 360. One of the best games ever made

This is probably my favorite Fallout game. The only bad part is that it occasionally crashes on me. I could fix it by setting my drivers back a few versions, but I'm not super tech savvy, don't know what I'm doing, and I don't wanna mess up my computer so I just deal with the crashes. Other than that, Great game.

I've never played a Fallout game before, so when I saw the Black Friday discount, I said "Why not?".
Absolutely worth my money. I'm surprised it runs on my laptop so well, and Low graphics still look good!
The amount of choices you can make is nothing like I ever experienced before!

A friend gifted me the game and has been watching me play through the game, I've enjoyed every minute and I've very thankful for it. The game is great and worth the money, I'd recommend this to anyone wanting to get into fallout.

It's a classic for a reason. One of, if not the only Fallout game where you actually see and feel the consequences of your decisions be visible before any sort of final conflict. They story is great, there is a TON of hidden quests and locations that unless you seek them out you might not even visit on a single given playthrough. Really enjoyed the DLC, each has it's own overarching theme which then ties together neatly with the history of the main game while providing background on who you the courier are/were.

Only downsides is this game is now 15-years old. It still crashes constantly, and only has one "auto-save' file so if your game crashes or something went sideways and you didn't save incrementaly throughout the past couple of hours? Well have fun repeating a large swathe of content. Also LOTS of quests still bug-out so it's handy to know some console commands to save you from reloading etc.

What can i say that hasn't already been said. the game is a classic, absolute staple of the industry [and seeming more and more like pure lightning in a bottle]. I played this mostly back on the 360, ever since getting a PC it's opened up a whole world for me. While i to am sick of the "mods, mods, mods" when it comes to fallout it's mostly for the bethesda ones since those suck, mods for vegas add to an already great experience instead of being replacements for content. i personally recommend going through vanilla at least once to experience the story as written without additions and the system/gameplay as we were. know how this game was and how despite the flaws became an all time classic. a word of warning for new modders recently nvse 6.4.1 was somehow scuffed and wouldn't let me get to the main menu. Don't know if it was something specific on my part but i just downloaded the older version and everything worked fine again except bad touch [a mod that adds damage sources to stuff like barbed wire and cactus]. if this has been fixed yet or if it was an issue of other mods not have been updated yet i do not know at this time. oh and to anyone new to this game farm NCR and Legion assassins to be rolling in caps, prioritize selling to the gun runners vendatron and that guy at 188 they always have the most caps, don't fall for the silver rush trap since you can't bring your guns in to sell. also be wary of casinos when with companions, back on 360 and here on PC companions lost their guns and there was no getting them back. Leave them outside unless it's a mod companion that has an assigned weapon that can't be lost like niner with his 9mm SMG or his eventual tommy gun.

Definitely the best Fallout game. The role-playing options are much broader, and the characters and events are, in my opinion, more engaging compared to the other games. The fate of the wastelands is entirely in your hands. Every faction has its own logical reasons, beliefs, and paths, and in this sense, the game pushes you into a philosophical reflection beyond your own worldview.

Back to the Fallout Roots, including the fun of shooting in the Wild West, along with a taste of crashes.
Examples (and I'm sure I'm missing some): (1) Saves won't load and instantly freeze up your game when it's made inside a building; (2) when swiftly moving through doors multiple times after each other, the game seems to give up and simply softlocks with a beautiful high-pitched noice to accompany your angryness; (3) When inside a building, seemingly with many NPCs around, the game sometimes cuts all audio (sounds of walking, background and even when talking to people) and will crash moments to minutes later.
It is a fun game, if you can look past the sometimes constant crashing, though. The story is well-written and fairly addictive once you start to get a feeling for the controls.

6,5/10
I played this game originally on the PS3, streamed it on my PS5, and now i'm playing it once again on my ROG laptop. I just cant stop coming back on account of how good it is.
If this game didnt brick itself and my computer forcing me to restart it every hour. It'd be peak game. Instead its just a crashing every hour peak game
This game is amazing, would highly reccomend. There are so many different directions you can go with the story and each side quest. Theres also so much to uncover and New Vegas looks dope as shit.
Probably the best RPG ever made. Bethesda open world with an actually good and truly reactive storyline.

This game has been a blast to return to again and again. Each playthrough I always seem to find something different even after pouring hours upon hours into a playthrough. Despite all the circumstances that troubled this game's development, (not to mention the trouble of getting it to run) this game is a gem. The characters feel well written, and the world seems to at times react to your choices and their inevitable consequences. In closing, if your PC can run this game and you want a great RPG, try this one out. Oh, and I recommend the DLC as well.

40hrs in and i forgot how much i loved these games after spending around 100hrs in fallout 3 I can wait to spend more time in this game. this game also encouraged me to try out and play the elder scrolls games. I highly reccomend playing this game!
Just played my 100th playthrough one of my saves got corrupted and moved over its inventory to my current save most games would break from this 10/10 game
Amazing game, probably closer to like 750ish hours from my original playthroughs on PS3 and current playthroughs on Steam and Xbox. Caesar can suck a fat one from my Ranger Sequoia.
This is the fucking best game of 2010, it totally deserves that damn remaster, come on Bethesda

The worst best game experience you will ever get.
It'll crash your computer five times a row and you'll still enjoy it.

There is a reason this game is considered one of the best RPGâ€™s of all time when it came out.

The majority of my experience with this game unmodded is from playing it on the Xbox 360. Yet on another steam account I have exponentially morehours than I do on this one with modded content.

Yes, this game is dated, but man for itâ€™s time it was a masterpiece.

You know the drill, positives, negatives, modding potential than overall score.

Where to begin for positives, for a game that came out in 2010 it was extraordinary. New Vegas, in my opinion, and many people will agree, has the best writing, dialogue, storytelling, lore drops, characters, companions, themes, in the entire franchise. Almost every character in this game responses and talks like a real person would. Characters have personalities and depth to them for a game that came out in 2010 that make you actually interested in them, especially the companions which are a highlight of this game. The RPG system in this game is classic with the point by system going all the way back to the 1980s. The factions have very interesting lore that are not just characters, but feel like actual living organizations with proper structure that havebenefits and faults of their own.

The guns and the gun designs in this game are wacky and fun. There are tons of memorable side characters, even one character that you made at the beginning of the game that gives you sort of the rundown of whatâ€™s going on and the starting location is memorable and you only talk to him for less than like three minutes! The writing for this game is that good for a game that came out in 2010.

The themes and how this game explores American exceptionalism and unregulated free market capitalisms consequences with how to react to them in a post apocalyptic world are exceptionally shown. Especially through the characters! 

The quests are very well designed with tons of different ways on tackling them there always feels like you have a choice in this game on how you want to handle a problem. That is extremely awesome! Choice is good!  

Faction leaders are multi faceted and extremely well conceptualized. The implementation of the bad karma faction in this game has probably one of the best and most intriguing faction leader in an open world rpg for that generation of games. Maybe even one of the best characters in that generation. 

The themes in this game are advanced for the time, everything from Trade contract corruption, the illusion of the grandeur democracy in some cases, Hegelian dialectics, the benefits and consequences of capitalism, understanding the root causes of tribal identity versus civilization.  All and more fantastically executed in immersive dialogue and storytelling.

Somewhat raunchy and racy the characters feel like theyâ€™ve been through or are in the post apocalypse. Most characters which you encounter in this game and thereâ€™s a decent amount for a game that came out in 2010.

The companions are extremely memorable in this game, all with great arcs, deep back stories, and ideas on how to benefit the wasteland or live in it. 

Quest design is detailed and you feel like your RPG stats  in the game progresses actually matter in terms of tackling problems!

Many memorable side quests that can end up completely different given how you choose handle them. Lots of RP potential in this game.

New Vegas has a great feel to it. The locations in the game you can tell weâ€™re made with love and passion Iâ€™ll be at there is the feeling that they were slightly rushed even for a game that came out in 2010.  There are multiple ways to handle dialogue situations a good portion of the time in the game when they matter that relate to your skill set. 

The Mojave is fun to explore, the radio host is exceptionally memorable, despite not even being a real person who doesnâ€™t talk that much. 

The factions that you decide with in this game, all four of them feel like youâ€™re engaging in a specific philosophy on how to actually handle the Mojave and the situation you find yourself in.

The antagonist for the first act of the game is memorable and insightful to how the Mojave just is in this game. The minor factions have interesting lore, good, and sometimes great quest lines and play important roles at the end of the story if you do their quests. 

The art design is neat and unique. You get the Vegas feel with the opening of casinos and all of that sort of stuff, but you also get the fallout feel a little bit with the whines yet also, this game has a realism to it that many of the other fallout games post fallout three donâ€™t have that the older titles sort of did.

All the DLCâ€™s for this game are exceptional well written and have worlds that are unique to the Mojave that feel like actual breathing world with characters and storylines that are entertaining! Themes explored include technological advancement, religion, philosophy, ideology, isolation, redemption, acceptance,  all masterfully told. In the DLC this game made me view a robot that doesnâ€™t even speak English has been one of the best companions in the game, that same DLC Lonesome Road, just so happens to have one of the best companions in an RPG ever with a complex grey moral compass, and interesting backstory.

Get the DLCs for this game. Theyâ€™re worth every single cent.

Obsidian knocked it out out of the park with this one. There are tons of more positives to mention but Iâ€™m running out of space.

Now onto the negatives. This game is not perfect. No game is, itâ€™s dated. Especially graphically, and the graphical improvements for this game donâ€™t really surpass anything that fallout three the game before it offered. The gunplay is lackluster, and customization is kinda there to be there. The Mojave kinda looks ugly, but ugly in a way that looks like youâ€™re truly in the post apocalypse desert with a touch of 50s Vegas flair. 

This game on PC is terribly optimized extremely glitchy and buggy, if you donâ€™t touch mods, get this game on console instead itâ€™s much more stable! 
This game is also buggy on PC, youâ€™re gonna wanna mod up on this one. Get golfers functioning collection for the vanilla pc experience.

Speaking of mods this Games community was one of the four runners in building Nexusgames.com with Oblivion, Morrowind and other titles.

There are loads of good companion, mods and story quest mods that are out there yet Iâ€™d argue youâ€™d have to search for them more then you you would later Bethesda titles modding community. 

Loads of mods that add new mechanics that can progress with you and money, sink mods that make the procrastination even more enjoyable.

Mod this game and if youâ€™re new, get one of the more recommended collections for this game.


For the time that this game came out with its DLCâ€™s iâ€™m giving it a 9.1 out of 10. It would be a 9.5 if the gun play and attachment system was better.

Nowadays, Iâ€™d give this a 7.1 if you can tolerate bad graphics and kind of an ugly design in comparison to modern stuff

With mods nowadays, I would score it to an 8.8 out of 10. If youâ€™re willing to go crazy, maybe an 8.9  Out of 10, you can make this game look really good with mods, and add some pretty good flushed out mechanics that work well with progress progressing through the Mojave! 

Post game functional ending Mojave squads and conquer the Mojave all have compatibility patches and after thinking about these three mods working together Iâ€™m bumping up the mod score to 9.1 out of 10!

Get this game and mod it on pc! Or if you donâ€™t like mods, get it cheap at the Xbox or PlayStation  store.

Fallout: New Vegas stands tall as one of the best entries in the entire Fallout series.
ðŸŽ­ Story & Roleâ€‘Playing
- The narrative depth is unmatched, giving players freedom to shape their own path in the Mojave Wasteland.
- Every faction, choice, and consequence feels meaningful, making replayability incredibly rewarding.
- The writing is sharp, morally complex, and full of memorable characters that make the world feel alive.
ðŸŒ„ Expansions & Value
- The expansion storiesâ€”Dead Money, Honest Hearts, Old World Blues, and Lonesome Roadâ€”are all worth the investment.
- Each DLC adds unique settings, challenges, and lore that enrich the core game.
- Together, they form a complete package that expands the New Vegas experience into something truly epic.
ðŸŽ® Why Itâ€™s a Series Highlight
- Compared to other Fallout titles, New Vegas strikes the perfect balance between openâ€‘world exploration, roleâ€‘playing depth, and narrative consequence.
- Itâ€™s a game that rewards curiosity, strategy, and moral reflection, making it stand out even years after release.
âœ¨ Final Thoughts
Fallout: New Vegas isnâ€™t just another Falloutâ€”itâ€™s the definitive Fallout experience. With its incredible storytelling and expansions that are genuinely worth the money, it remains one of the most impactful RPGs of its generation.

This game is old. You cannot run. The game crashes at times. The game is also old. Don't judge it too harshly on presentation though.

The characters are given context, motivations, and a human outlook. Every faction has it's own reputation system and actions affect multiple factions. Nearly every mission is interesting and there are so many great moments in this game it's impossible not to love this game by the time you finish the main story. 

One of the best games out there. Amazing what they managed to achieve in less than two years.

It is an ok game, it has its flaws and a very overbearing community, but at the end of the day the game is very enjoyable. This is added on to by a very active modding community that puts out absolute bangers consistently, plus it can be further added onto if you buy Fallout 3 and combine both games into Tales of Two Wastelands, allowing you to play both games at the same time while remaining 87% compatible with all New Vegas mods and about 50% compatible with Fallout 3 mods, though I would only recommend smaller F3 mods to ensure stability. Very much worth $20 for the game and its add-ons, and it goes on sale somewhat often.

One of the best fallout games ever made. Despite being made on a shoestring budget with an ungodly deadline and being next to unplayable without community mods to help optimise it. 

Having played it first on the xbox 360 in 2010 and again on PC. Most Fallout fans will nostalgically come back to New Vegas one way or  another. Whether it's because of its branching story and quest lines which have actual consequences. Dialogue options which are tailored to your characters unique build. Or immersive world which draws you in as the hours tick by. 

Like with most bethesda titles, all can agree it is a buggy mess. And you will need community mods to stabilise it lest you be subject to repeat crashes or frozen loading screens. I am by no means a seasoned modder and It took me the best part of a day watching youtube tutorials to get them all working. 

But once you do get it working, boy is it worth it. Obsidian did an amazing job with the limited resources they were given. Having seen the behind the scenes article and youtube videos covering it, it is remarkable we even got a game. But despite that they gave us the best fallout game of the bethesda era.
Some rare crashes here and there so make sure you quicksave often, but other than that - it runs great after all these years.
my favorite fallout game, amazing plot and setting. truly one of the most immersive games ive ever played.

Gameplay with a PS5 controller is instant memories unlocked from when this game first came out. All DLC is working smoothly.

After playing hundreds of hours (most by less than legal means), here is what I actually love about this game:

- Bethesda jank? Try Obsidian jank. Turning into an airplane? Only in New Vegas.
- You can gamble like a degenerate and have a duel with the dealers if you lose... only in New Vegas!
- Different ammo types in the GRA DLC? Only in New Vegas...
- A main quest that isn't the video game equivalent of a sleeping pill? Only in New Vegas.
- DLCs that has great stories, mechanics, characters, and great value? Only in New Vegas!
- Factions that don't make your political theory feel worthless? Only in New Vegas... if you do have some.
- Fallout 3 but there is more than just a reskin? Only in New Vegas.

Overall, pretty solid title. Considering the game and the DLCs aren't half as costly as most modern titles... what are you waiting for? You want to play Fallout 3 to compare it?

Picked this up day of release only for it to become one of my favorite RPG's ever. Currently revisting it to 100%. Truly a masterpiece, cannot begin to recommend it enough, the replayability is endless.

ðŸ˜  Review (PC/Steam): Fallout: New Vegas - The PC Masterpiece That Refuses to Run.
Rating: 3/5 Stars (If Stable, it would be 5/5)
Fallout: New Vegas remains an absolute monument of the RPG genre. Its unparalleled writing, complex moral choices, and richly designed quests make it a game I desperately want to love. However, as a long-time PC gamer and Steam user, I cannot in good conscience recommend purchasing this game without a severe technical warning. The experience is constantly shattered by an unforgivable level of instability.
ðŸ’” The Bugs That Ruin the Experience
The disappointment is compounded on PC because we often rely on community patches and workarounds to get these older games running smoothly. In the case of New Vegas, this reliance is mandatory, and the fact that even these dedicated community fixes fail to address core issues is infuriating.The Unfixed Steam Version: The base Steam version is functionally broken. It crashes frequently, struggles with infinite loading screens, and has massive performance dips. It's appalling that Bethesda/Obsidian has allowed this masterpiece to remain in such a pathetic state on its main distribution platform.
The Vicious Cycle of Fixes: I've spent more time troubleshooting this game than actually playing it. When a major bug occursâ€”specifically, the one that renders certain critical areas like a "glitched black hole" of instabilityâ€”the common advice is to install mods, run specific loaders, or perform file edits. The ultimate frustration is that none of these common, time-consuming fixes work for the worst bugs.
Progress Lost to Code: The worst part is the persistent, game-breaking failure: quest triggers that stall, NPCs that vanish, or entire locations that instantly crash the game. This isn't quirky fun; it's active sabotage of the gameplay loop. Losing hours of progress because the game's flawed engine simply gives up is an unacceptable failure of product maintenance.
The Bottom Line: Pure Frustration
Fallout: New Vegas has all the makings of a 10/10 game, but I rate it a frustrating 6/10 because its technical instability actively prevents me from enjoying it. Unless you have the patience of a saint and don't mind the constant, heart-breaking prospect of losing your save file, wait for a truly stable remaster. The brilliance of the writing simply isn't worth the sheer anger caused by the broken code.

ive played for 3 hours and the game crashed 5 times - and not only that, it also required a full pc reboot to actually exit the game. im probably gonna have to look into optimisation mods to be able to play the game. the game itself is good - but i cannot give it a good review if its not playable in vanilla state

Unplayable on Windows 11. Whenever I try to leave Doc Mitchell's house, the game completely freezes on the loading screen and I have to restart my PC to recover from it.

There is a game breaking bug that prevents you from loading save files from the main menu. When you try to load a save file from the main menu you get stuck in a infinite loading screen. A work around was found to just start a new game and then load your previous save. That gets old really fast. This particular bug has been around for 8+ years. I only found this out after surfing the forums of several different websites where LOTS of other people were experiencing the same issues. Even after using the work around the game crashes OFTEN and can even lock you in a different infinite loading screen just going through doors. My issues began only after I arrived in NIFTON. I saw on several other forums this seemed to be the case as well. 

Some forums said to download different MOD fixes that would fix the issues but there were too many people saying they downloaded the mods and the infinite loading screens were still present and the game still crashes. 

The game itself is great, I remember playing on a friends 360 but never got too far in the game. It seems like I wont be able to finish this game on PC due to the game breaking bugs. 

I HIGHLY recommend NOT BUYING THIS GAME.

The movement in the game is extremely slow I even have a perk for movement speed when crouching and even when I was 2x faster crouching than I was running it still felt like I was barely moving or maybe it is just because the desert is so vast, having a game based in a desert is a terrible idea, in most open world games you have cool scenery to look at whilst travelling or the locations are not that far away from each other, in New Vegas you have A LITERAL DESERT??? it is painful to travel anywhere in this game because it will take 10 minutes of STARING AT SAND for you to get there it is MIND-NUMBING its worse than watching paint dry, I would rather watch paint dry.

The Story starts off good with a revenge based intro to the game [spoiler] where you get shot in the head [/spoiler] its not as strong as Fallout 4s [spoiler] having your wife killed in front of you and your child kidnaped after meeting them and building a background on yourself and your family [/spoiler] New Vegas does not build a background on you apart from that you are a courier the rest is for you to decide but its still an alright hook, the start of the game is alright but as you progress to Benny it turns out its not the end game goal that you think it is and there is no build up at all then its just sort of a meaningless moment and it pushes you onto another story line which is barely connected to Benny and which I have no idea about because I didn't research for 10 hours about the background lore of all 500 factions, its like starting a whole new game, absolutely terrible storyline it would have been 10x better if they just made it end at Benny or just removed Benny all together and made you start as a member of the NCR or something, and it gets to a point where there is too much dialogue and too many choices and quests and information to the point that it just gets boring and there is no gameplay and you are just fast traveling about and talking to people especially once you get to the strip and the robot gives you like 10 quests it just gets to the point where it is annoying to play, or throughout the game characters will just talk about absolute garbage that I could not care less about its like each character wants to tell you their whole life story when you ask them a simple question I COULD NOT CARE LESS IM TRYING TO KILL BENNY, allot of it can be shown through environmental storytelling but instead they create a dialogue slop just packing as much information they can into it, its like reading a book its just boring I'm trying to play a game, you might as well play a visual novel with the amount of dialogue in this game or just remove the gameplay all together. In short Dialogue hell, bad main story.

With all of these issues stacked up at a certain point I just wanted the game to end but it kept dragging on to the point where I had to quit.

As somebody who's not plagued by nostalgia for NV I can keep this completely unbiased and factual

-The story is ok, most definitely above average but not great, like 6 or 7 /10
-Caracter creation and skill tree is insanely good, a million times better then FO4 and the rp element in rpg are definetly very good in NV, but sadly thats it, that all there is to it
-The combat is so janky and bad not only in comparison to FO4 or FO76 but to any other non-FO game as well that you will have to rely on VATS exclusively.
-But the worst is the world, it's so empty, like actually boring and totally empty. For a quest you have to walk from A to B, nothing new or revolutionary there but in other games you can at least see something or do something or meet somebody or anything at all whatever, in NV however you are alone in an empty world, you walk for hours without seeing literally anything at all, that's not some kind of enjoyment of solitude, that's just boring

Ignore all the nostalgic reviews about this game, do not buy it, I will explain
This game is bugged beyond belief, and is quite possibly the most buggy I have in my entire collection, and I do not mess around with that, it is literally outdated and so buggy that it's more stress than you really need... it should not be sold on Steam, I consider it a scam...

Why? 

It's a 32bit application that reserves 2gb of memory from the RAM, but also memory leaks from cell buffering and LOD rezzes. Despite being a 32bit application capable of 4Gb of ram usage, it allocates only 2Gb instead of 4Gb, and seems to have an additional buffer of 2-3Gb, which..... I'm even unsure why... It's never actually used.... Whenever the games RAM climbs above 1Gb it will crash.... It's unfortunate, and not really known why, other than it's an old 32Gb game for consoles and PC from older times...

This means: You will need a mod to increase the allocation size of the memory to 4Gb and manually adjust it's allocations, as well as other gross and disgusting hacks and mods to open up the memory (Do not disable DEP or you could corrupt Windows), and EVEN with these stability fixes, it will still crash.... 

Ontop of all of this the game is setup with a grotesque ini file for both FalloutPref.ini and Fallout.ini that expunges important substrings, such as bBorderless, and bMouseAcceleration... 

The game includes a horrifying mouse acceleration that will absolute annoy you, there is no such thing as aim so you will be using VATS a lot unless you add bMouseAcceleration=0, and a series of other configuration edits that were never included in the games files....

Ontop of this, the games settings and preferences do not actually work, you cannot go Borderless, Windowed, or set resolutions higher than 1480p in the settings, or both the ini configuration files, and this will require, yes.... Another mod..... 

Unfortunately... Fallout4 is very much the same where it requires tweaking ini configuration files and adding substrings inside to get borderless windowed 1920p 

So:
Major Instability
Lots of crashing
Lots of saving the game every time you kill or harvest
Forced mouse acceleration that is extremely aggressive and requires VATs
Possibly mods or "tips/tricks/memory hacks" that could even corrupt windows itself if you are not careful
No Windowed mode
No Borderless
No 1920 resolution
Oh also inventory bugs that cause you to lose items out of the inventory oddly. Especially during a cell buffer... Which seems to also be the cause of memory leaking
